name: The Swindle
description: The Swindle is a steampunk cybercrime caper about breaking into buildings, hacking their systems, stealing all their cash, and quickly running away again before the police show up.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 and up Processor: 2.4Ghz Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: GeForce 8800 equivalent or higher DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 1 GB available space Sound Card: What is this, 1991? Yes a sound card. Onboard is fine. Additional Notes: If playing on a Laptop, please make sure it has a dedicated gfx card; on-board cards will struggle.

reviews.review_text: A very enjoyable game in the style of Rogue Legacy...at least in the sense that death forces a character change.  Each thief is randomised, and you will want to protect the cooler looking ones from dying.  I won't describe the features, because the page does that well, but this is everything an indie game SHOULD be; new and refreshing, but grounded in familiarity. The only criticism i have is that it would be nice if the starting thief was randomised, rather than the same one all the time. Highly recommended.

I love the central idea that this game is built around. But I don't love the heavily flawed controls, and constant bugs and glitches. Just in the last few days of playing, I've encountered many glitches. I've gotten stuck in the scenery, I've had the Teleporter ability completely glitch out and freeze my character in mid-animation so I had to terminate them, I've had enemies somehow see me through solid objects and instantly kill me. When it plays well and how it's supposed to, it's really enjoyable, but when you die several times from glitches and terrain weirdness beyond your control, the gameplay feels cheap and unsatisfying.   The controls are not tight enough to serve a game which demands constant careful traversal. Sometimes I've slid down stairs onto mines, or had the jump button suddenly become unresponsive. Many of the commands sometimes feel like they're not responding. The game simply does not give you the control and polish you need for the level of skill it wants from you. I love the idea, the challenge, and the look, but the shaky controls, and frustrating glitches make it too flawed a gem for me to recommend. When I die in a game I want it to be because I screwed up, not because the game suddenly decided to get my character stuck in a wall.

I don't normally bother reviewing games as I leave it to the 'professionals'. But I feel this game is not being completely fairly treated by the press - but read the VG247 review for an (IMO) accurate review.  It's a great little game for the price and far better than some of the review scores it's getting. Yes, it can be infuriating at times but it's designed that way so I don't see that as a bad point. Great graphics and sound and moreish gameplay.  I thought my 16 yr old nephew would think it was rubbish as he's been brought up with 3D and doesn't want to play much else other than FIFA, F1 (sorry mate) - but he loved it and we had a great afternoon playing it, laughing at each others pathetic attempts and greedy misfortunes.  Glad to see steam users rating is mostly positive!! The majority are correct!! BUT it might not be for everyone.  UPDATE Played 9 hours now. In that time I've really started to see how the game works and how I could beat it. You become more skilled so even when you have to begin again with no upgrades you know the early levels will be a doddle because you have improved and you make better decisions based on past knowledge. Don't want to give away any more. 100 days hah ha ha!!!!  Forgot to say - try not to lose over 10 grand when trying to get back to the airship. I only needed one more second.. the amount of Â£notes looked great floating down, but I nearly killed my cat!! (sorry Izzy)

Being a thief is hard, especialy if you rush in without some sort of plan. Smash a window, grab the loot and get out. That sort of thing. Well, this will probably get you killed. It's all about being patient, calculating your jumps and using your abilities as best as you can.   And that's exactly where The Swindle is a brilliant game. Each ability is usefull. Some don't seem that usefull but it's all about how you play the game. Knowing where the computers are seems like a waste of resource when it's that or a tripple a jump, but information makes the job easier. Tripple jumping to, sure. If you are unlucky and face a lot of empty void between too ledges.  Anyway, managing your money, establishing 'the best buying plan', min/maxin risks and rewards while in missions, figuring out how to get that heavily guarded chest...it's not just a action game, it's a puzzle action game. And with procedural genereration of terrain, the same situation is hardly encountered again. As for how it's proceduraly generated, well, don't expect the same few rooms over and over. There will be similarities but a small underground map can be as easily encountered as a huge 3 storys with a one tower or two. The map are diverse, there may not be enough sort of level but the increasing difficulty and payout rewards make them just the right amount.  One last thing, the music and sounds are good. It's just what you would expect of a steampunk era, and even more what you would expect for a stealth steampunk mood.

The Swindle is a procedurally-generated, real-time semi-roguelike solo heist game. You break into randomly-generated houses swarming with robot security guards and attempt to steal all the cash. Eventually you can move up the socio-economic ladder and break into richer buildings like banks and casinos. But it's all moving towards one goal: hack into the AI that is about to be unleashed on the city in 100 days.  There's two levels of failure in this game: You can trip the alarm, or you can die. If you trip the alarm, you get a frantic little while to scarper before the police show up. If you die, you lose all money on this heist and a day towards the deadline.  It's an interesting game. Not as refined as, say, Spelunky. The platforming is a little awkward, and occasionally the level can provide you with an impossible house. There's a nice upgrade tree that you need to climb, but probably cannot get it all before the deadline.  There's lots of great little elements. The heists themselves are neat, with steadily increasing dangerous foes. The atmosphere is great - footsteps change as you go from rooftop to floor, and the rain pattering on rooftops dulls as you go inside. And my favourite, Big Ben chimes when it hits the top of the hour in the real world!  The controls and feel need a bit of polish, but overall it's quite a neat game. It's a good colleague and counterpoint to Spelunky - a campaign rather than a run, upgrades instead of items, patience and care rather than running to the finish.

Amazing game, quite difficult. I love the gloom effect and ambiance, the visuals are very nice. You're a thief, your job is to rob houses and progress on to better districts. Living in space and using your shuttle to land near houses which are generated randomly, you will never get the same house twice. You can buy agility perks, abilties like hacking, tools like bombs and unlock better districts. Robots patrolling, cameras, mines and even the polices when you sound the alarm, do not get caught. When you die you keep your perks but the thief is replaced with someone else. This game had me at Steampunk but all in all its a very fun game.

Cruel learning curve, unforgiving level generation, sparse tutorials, and spotty controls. Cant say I didn't enjoy this game though. If you buy it, you will not finish it on your first 100 days, I guarantee. You'll also get mad and throw your controller. Its very challenging, but a wonderful game. The feeling of taking your time through the banks, trying to get the last computer hacked, when you've failed the last 10 heists and are running out of time is an incredible tension.   Not for everyone, but definitely worth it for me.
One of the most satisfying, frustrating and addictive games I've played in a long time. Can't recommend enough. Buy it now!
Right now, the gam is hard as all hell and the controlls are really clunky and un-responsive. BUT, i highly recommend this game to anyone with a rage problem.

First of all: The Swindle is a  really fun  game to play, a truly well done combination of stealth and platforming within a rogue-like mechanic. And don't worry if you are, like me, not a big fan of hardcore stealth games: this one has exacly the right amount of stealth so that you cannot easily rush through levels but you don't have to be planning each move for ten minutes either.   As a steampunk crook, you have a hundred days of heists to prepare for the big one. Through these 100 days, you will, ahem, 'earn' money from every (procedurally generated) house you visit, and then use it to buy upgrades that will make you much better at your job. Those upgrades range from athletic ones, like double or triple jumps, to gadgets like bombs or bugs to help you steal more money, to ones that make the police take more time to appear when you set off an alarm during a heist. Which you will do, like, millions of times.  And yes, you will get caught. And you will die. A LOT. And you will curse at everything around you. And then you'll say to yourself 'okay, just one more heist'. And twenty heists later you will still be there, telling yourself that it will be just one more, and still playing. Remember Spelunky? Well, yes, that.  The graphics, the music, the whole ambientation of the game are just fantastic, and add up to the great feeling of immersion The Swindle has.   Don't be scared of reviews mentioning that controls are bad: even if that might have been the case for some people on the release date version of the game, sucessive patches have made them much better. In fact, the tweaks that are being added little by little by Dan Marshall on every patch are making the game even better and more fun to play while making the learning curve much gentler for first-time players.  So, long story short:  go buy The Swindle!

1. If your game revolves aroung robot security, personal mechanical enhancements, and hacking computers why are you calling it steampunk? You're getting your punks confused mate. 2. Semi random level generation in a stealth game is very difficult to pull off since most stealth games are basicly puzzles for the player to solve. Random levels in this case mean mediocre puzzles. 3. All this would be forgiven if it felt good to move and jump. It does not. Everything is sloppy and impercise. Add to that one hit deaths and you have a game that I cannot recomend.

After one hour playing this game i've died 12 times. Every time you die, your character sex and face changes and no level is the same since it's procedurally generated.  You have your flying hideout where you can upgrade your various abilities and create gadgets using your workbench  Feels like a good mix of gunpoint with games like spelunky and such, but in glorious 3d & solid 60 fps. Besides from the flawless technical side, the game has it's unique flavor. I easily see myself diving further in it, to get the big heists and the big toys to make myself a millionaire -virtually of course-

Thoroughly adoring this game, it's frustrating, frantic, but fun as hell! Really amazing soundtrack too.  It's got some issues though, the randomly generated nature of the levels can make it more than a little irritating if you don't have some specific upgrades, such as the ability to hack security cameras, as one can be directly over a computer terminal and you won't be able to hack it without setting off the alarm. In fact, hacking computer terminals can be the only real way to get money in the game, as random cash found around the level rarely adds up to much. It would've been a little more balanced had the random cash amounted to a little more, and the cash from hacking computers accounted for a little less. But all that aside, it's a thoroughly good game.

getting used to the movement takes a while because not only you have to consider the platforms you are going to land but also the trajectory of your jump thanks to the wall sticking mechanic and can lead to annoying deaths but im not always bothered by it because most of my deaths were from being too greedy or from fall damage  there is a way to negate fall damage entirely but it's not a passive skill so be very careful. still a game that challenges you but gives you all the time in the world to decide what to do so i know if i mess up i know it was all my fault ( or i was startled by a random skype message :O ).  love it!!

I've clocked up about 11 hours in The Swindle so far, and I've not even come close to reaching the halfway point of the game. This is mostly, I'm not afraid to say, down to my incompetence, which this game isn't afraid to remind me of. Regularly.  To describe the core of the game - steal as much cash from each procedurally generated level as possible, without dying - makes it sound simple and repetitive, but that's sort of the genius. Your goal and the way you achieve it often is simple, but your one small mistake will cost you and you will hate yourself for it every time.  'I just need to drop down, whack that guard and the jump over those spikes,' you think, just before mistiming your initial drop, getting spotted by the guard, and jumping into those spikes in a state of panic. Of course, you then try and make up for that mistake by doing something more risky next time (you need to make up for that lost cash somehow!) and, well, you can probably guess why I've barely scratched the surface in 11 hours.  There are a huge amount of upgrades available for you to vary your approach and tactics for the inevitable sixth and seventh playthrough, which often leads to those confidence-dashing moments, too. Y'know, just as you found that perfect combination of upgrades that means that this guy is no longer a threa--oh, he got me.  I've read a few comments saying that it needs a tutorial of some sort. It really, really doesn't. The controls and the mechanics are as simple as they come, it's the real understanding of how you use the simple tools you're provided with, plus those you 'provide'* yourself, that brings the real fun here and that would be taken away with any sort of guide. If you really want help, watch 10 minutes of someone else play it on YouTube and you'll know more than enough to get going.  Basically, it's infuriatingly brilliant because it's always happy to give you the perfect opportunity to â¥â¥â¥â¥ things up, just as you think you've got a handle on it.   * I mean steal. You play a dirty, dirty thief.
Imagine Spelunky in Steampunk London.   It's actually The Swindle

I am terrible at this game, but I keep wanting to play it and get better. I'm mad at my own inability, not the game.  It is a difficult rouge-like, Mark of the Ninja / Heisting crossover that makes you angry because you got too greedy, slipped and fell to your death. I can only describe the feeling of this moment as a similar feeling to the one when you've spent the past hour cooking, only to serve it up, trip and have the plate (and all the food with it) fall to the ground smashing and smearing into lots of pieces on the linoleum lining of your kitchen floor.  It's heartbreaking yet beautifully poetic.

Just the bestest game. Controls can be fiddly, but in 4-5 hours, you'll have it down.  I like the difficulty level. Like Sunless Sea, or FTL, your first few games will be a wash, but that's ok. Full games can be quite quick, and it's really ok to lose lots of operatives. Items could be a little more expensive, but otherwise, buy. Buy! Buy now!

I've never been as drawn into a game as much as this one. The contstant changes in level design coupled with contantly rising stakes and difficulty make a very edge-of-your-seat experience and require a bit of creativity and flexability to work through.     The only setback of this game are when you are inevetabley put in an impossible situation and either get killed trying to beat it or having to kill yourself. This can happen a few times in a row, and when you also screw yourself over, can destroy the time limt given.    I like this game, I really do, but I think I'll end up punching through my monitor if this keeps up.

I'm not really sure how to go about reviewing this. I suppose I will just say this: when I die and scream profanity at my monitor it is shortly followed by a shake of the head, and a muttered, 'I'm such an idiot.' Followed by another hour of playing. The point being, when I die in this game it's because I got impatient or just generally suck, not any jankery on behalf of the game. That's not to say there isn't any jankery, it's just the kind that's on purpose. It's fun. Buy it.
If you want to plan your next move carefully and then watch your character spazz out and fall into a bed of spikes. This is the game for you.

Spelunky meets Dishonored for a spot of burglary. No do-overs. No quicksaves. No 'easy' difficulty setting. I learned how to move, predict enemy patrol patterns, earn bonus multipliers for successful 'heists' and upgrade thieves with neat gadgets. Blowing up mines with a remote detonator is fantastic! I laugh, I get annoyed, I seethe with rage...and because I'm into unforgiving gameplay I'm loving every minute of it.
i would recommend this game to others. it's fun, fast, and replayable.

The Swindle is a brill steampunk steal-em-up adventure in the Spelunky mould that which is well worth giving a go. The journey from neophyte footpad to master burglar is empowering and the procedural generation keeps everything fresh and interesting. If you can look past the odd glitchy level with nothing to steal and the sometimes sluggish controls there is a lot to love about Size Five Games crime caper. Now please excuse me I'm off back to the slums... it's time to get my loot on.

I've really enjoyed Dan Marshall's games ever since I played the two Been There, Dan That adventure games, The Swindle is quite possibly the best stealth game I've ever played. Usually when I play games that have a stealth mode, I just end up being loud and killing everyone anyways. That's impossible to do in The Swindle because the consequences of being discovered in The Swindle are devastating.   Backing up a bit, in The Swindle you play a thief, whose goal (in addition to making a ton of cash) is to stop the police from inacting the Basilisk, a device that will stop all future theivery. You have 100 days to do it and you need to spend those 100 days working your way up from $0 to enough cash to purchase all the tools you need to steal the heavily guarded Basilik.   And wow. There are some fun skills here. Teleporters, hacking bugs, bombs, cloaking devices, etc. All of which are vital to remaining undetected. Because if a guard does see you... all hell breaks loose. Every guard on the level is chasing you, heavy duty security door are closing everywhere, and an unstoppable police backup is on the way. So yea, it is vital to sneak in, take out the guards one by one, hack the bank accounts and sneak out of there.   The difficulty curve definitely ramps up as you go along, so you have to figure out the best way to spend your money on skill upgrades. It's quite possible to upgrade the wrong skills at the wrong time and find yourself completely outclassed by the neighborhood security systems.   Overall, a very fun, challenging, and unique game, that in my mind, has absolutely reached the pinnacle of what stealth gaming should be.

I played through a 100 days in the game before I asked for a refund.  This game is difficult, not only is it difficult, but the controls are terrible, whether you're on the keyboard or controller. (And you really need to be using the controller.)  The difficulty scale gets completely out of hand if you don't have basic upgrades, and even though there's a fair amount of upgrades in the airship, you run out of time before you can probably buy five of them, let alone fully upgrade them.  The gimmick of this game is that it keeps getting harder to scale, but it's too easy to die. If you miss one level you're completely screwed and will lose when you run out of time. Oh yeah, the time function in this game.  The way 'days' work in this game is that you have 100 of them before all your stats are reset. Yeah. Every bit of progress you achieved is deleted after a small amount of time. 'Oh, but I only managed to buy hacking, bombs, and no fall damage upgrades! How am I supposed to get all those cool gadgets that allow me to see where things are faster, and delay the police?' Well, you don't. It's completely impossible. If someone actually managed to beat this game and get all the upgrades, I would be amazed.  But hey, maybe you want a game that's completely unbeatable, but I like feeling as if I'm a god at the end of games, not trip on my own shoes and die when I find the final boss.

Fun concept, poor execution. about a third of the levels are actually unbeatable because of bad placement of enemies or environement tiles. You will die but not because of errors you made but simply because of unbeatable obstacles generated by the RNG environement, The problem is especially glaring in the early levels.

I have spent a fair amount of time in this game, but i can not recommend this game to anyone unless they enjoy being punished by the games own bad controls and collision detection, a creative concept with a fitting art style and good pacing with lots of new content and mechanics being introduced throughout the game. if you enjoy stealth platformers then you will have lots of fun with this game. apart from the controls the biggest complaint i have is enemies spawning in and being able to see you from where they spawn, there is no way you can prevent this from happening if you have a low spec pc, and even on high specs it can still be a problem later in the game.

Tentative recommendation: I like this game and want to like it more, because it should be right up my street, but I think my (admittedly ancient) machine may not be up to it: the controls and screen movement all feel jumpy.

I'm not usually into stealth games but I really enjoyed this. The steampunk setting works really well and the music is fantastic. The controls definitely aren't as tight as they could be which can lead to some frustrating deaths, but you get used to them after a while, and there are upgrades you can buy to make it easier to get around the levels.  Your options are limited in the beginning, but once you get a feel for the game and string together a few successful runs you'll be able to start unlocking upgrades that allow you to attempt more difficult heists for bigger rewards. The more abilities you unlock, the more possibilities open up on how to tackle a level. The difficulty ramps up at a steady pace, so as you become more versatile the levels become more challenging to keep things interesting. This is a stealth game at heart so it pays to be patient, scope the place out and make a plan. It can be tricky, especially on the later levels, but it's super satisfying to get in, steal every last penny, and get out again without being caught! :D  If you're into stealth (and steampunk!) and are willing to give it a chance I highly recommend giving it a shot.

Loved the game, controls aren't tight but that didn't kill it for me. What got REALLY frustrating was when I started getting into later levels, and enemies began to detect and kill me through thin walls and doors. There are points where you HAVE to rely on doors and blockaided windows to avoid detection, but the game sometimes just decides to kill you anyway.

A great game for hardcore players. The Swindle provides for the player a great challenge with high skill floor and a high skill ceiling both, which when surmounted gives the player great joy as he can appreciate the amount of skill and cleverness required to succesfully accomplishing heists.  When the player is first thrown into the game, there's very little hand-holding and explanation of how the game works. The player learns by experience, and typically by failing a lot. When the player finally thinks he has grasped the obstacles that were presented to him, his advance introduces challenges anew, putting on new twists and requiring even greater skill to surpass. At the same rate the player earns more and more tools that give more ways to complete a level.  The game's difficulty is easily explained: One of the core features limits the number of times you can play through all the levels, and at first these attempts are not enough for the player to reach the end as he must spend many of those by learning through failure, and the failure consequences must be faced. But the end result is that the perseverant players are rewarded with a lot of development in their personal ability to play the game. If a lower difficulty level was allowed, most would simply use it instead and not be able to fully appreciate their development.  Personally, after finally beating it, I came back for more, and found myself becoming better and better at it, completing the game faster and harder each time. This development and the pleasure it brings is the experience the game wants to invoke, and for me, it was utterly succesful.
